Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if his attention has been drawn to claims recently made by the Green Peace Organisation that the direct discharge of waste from the Windscale nuclear reactor plant into the Irish Sea has resulted in the plutonium poisoning of fish and has had other adverse ecological consequences; if he accepts these charges; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Spring) Dick Spring
Speaker.P: I am aware of the claims made by the Green Peace Organisation regarding discharges of radioactive waste into the Irish Sea from the nuclear reprocessing plant at Windscale in Cumbria. The organisation have recently outlined their views on this matter to the Minister of State at my Department. Basically, the organisation have claimed that the discharges have led to radioactive pollution of fisheries in the Irish Sea. I understand from the Windscale plant and that these statutory body responsible for advising the Government on these matters, that small quantities of plutonium are included in the low level liquid effluents discharged to the north-east Irish Sea from the windscale plant and that these discharges are required to conform with the various safety standards laid down by the relevant international bodies. I am further informed by the Nuclear Energy Board that the radiological significance of the plutonium concentrations in fish caught in the Irish Sea is negligible.

Preliminary discussions have taken place about the possibility of concluding a formal Inter-Governmental Agreement between Ireland and the United Kingdom on the question of exchange of information about nuclear installations generally and the possibility of discharges from them. When the Paris Convention which deals with marine discharges from land based sources has been formally ratified, our position on the question of nuclear waste discharges from such sources will be reviewed with a view to initiating discussions with the United Kingdom authorities in accordance with the terms of the Convention.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning Mr. Molony Mr. Molony
Speaker.P: and Mr. Manning asked the Minister for Industry and Energy what the effects of charging the Whitegate refinery from use as a refinery to use as a storage depot for refined products would be on: (a) the staff currently employed in the refinery; (b) the security of oil supplied in this country; and (c) the cost to the Irish energy user.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: It is not possible to say what the effects of using Whitegate as a storage depot would be until such a policy, if contemplated, was specifically detailed and costed. There would be a number of policy options, such as, for example, whether or not to mothball the refining hardware which would have a significant impact on employment levels and costs. Certainly there would be a reduction in staff employed both in the refinery itself and in ancillary services. The effect on security of oil supplies, apart from the loss of flexibility in not having an active refinery, would also depend on the volume and type of oil stored. The capital or financing requirement of having all the refinery tankage full with oil products would be of the order of $70 million or an financing charge of the order of $9 million per annum. The operating cost would be up to $2 million per annum in addition to this.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Irish National Petroleum Corporation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning Mr. Molony Mr. Molony
Speaker.P: and Mr. Manning asked the Minister for Industry and Energy the functions and purposes of the Irish National Petroleum Corporation; whether he is satisfied that the corporation has fulfilled these functions and purposes; whether it is the function of the Irish National Petroleum Corporation to make a contribution to the efficiency and competitiveness of the oil supply industry in this country to the benefit of consumers; and, if so, if he is satisfied that the corporation is fulfilling this function.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: The detailed objectives of the Irish National Petroleum Corporation Limited are set out in the corporation's memorandum of association available in the Companies Registration Office. The working objectives are contained in the recent annual reports of the corporation which are available in the Library of the House. I am, however, arranging to circulate a copy of the latter in the Official Report. It will be noted that these objectives embrace a function on the lines specified in the Deputies' question.

The scope of the corporation's original functions was very substantially changed when, following Government decisions in 1982 to acquire the Whitegate refinery, the corporation was entrusted with the operation of the refinery.

While the success of a body like the INPC should be assessed against the totality of its approved objectives, I regard the impact of the corporation's activities on the efficiency and competitiveness of the oil industry here as a crucial aspect. This is a matter which must weigh very significantly in the Government's review of future policy on the corporation and its operations.
The Deputies will appreciate that it would not be appropriate for me, at this stage, to express views other than as an input to consideration of the matter by the Government in due course.
Objectives of the Corporation

MainHeading.P: 1. To provide for the supply of a significant part of the oil requirements of the Irish market on terms which are as secure as possible in duration and continuity and in accordance with policies approved by the Minister for Industry and Energy.

2. To operate within the Irish oil industry and market in a manner which will promote orderly development, bearing in mind objective No. 1 above, the national situation and other commercial interests involved.
3. To develop and maintain an economic operation which contributes to the efficiency of the oil industry in Ireland.

4. To carry out duties as designated by the Minister for Industry and Energy in relation to the development of indigenous hydrocarbon resources, including functions arising from the State's participation rights provided for in petroleum exploration licences.

5. To afford professional advice and assistance and to undertake specific functions and operations on behalf of the Minister for Industry and Energy in relation to the provision, transportation, refining and storage of petroleum and to all oil industry matters.
6. To maintain a continuous review of international supply trends and keep the Minister for Industry and Energy advised of important developments.
7. To promote the use and development of Irish natural resources and to promote an enhanced trading value for Irish exports where possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning Mr. Molony Mr. Molony
Speaker.P: and Mr. Manning asked the Minister for Industry and Energy (a) the quantities of fuel oil which the ESB were obliged to purchase from the Irish National Petroleum Corporation in 1982 at prices above the prevailing market price; (b) the cost to the ESB of this differential; (c) the extra cost on the price of electricity as a result of this differential; and (d) the amount of such oil actually delivered to the ESB.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: In 1981 the Electricity Supply Board entered into a contract with the Irish National Petroleum Corporation for the supply in 1982 of 250,000 tonnes of heavy fuel oil representing about one-third of the board's fuel oil requirements in 1982. Between January and April 1982, 81,000 tonnes were sold and delivered to the board under an agreed contract at an average price of $206.7 per tonne. In August 1982 the Government decided that the board should purchase by the end of the year the balance of the contracted quantity, that is, 169,000 tonnes, at a crude-related price of $195 per tonne. The board received delivery of 20,000 tonnes of this quantity. With the changed situation in the fuel oil market and in agreement with the Department, the board and the corporation arranged that the latter would sell 140,000 tonnes on behalf of the former on the open market and the board would pay the corporation the difference between the sales price and the crude-related price. This difference averaged $20.3 per tonne. Because of the existence of premia related to suitability of the material for further processing and low sulphur content this arrangement was beneficial both to the corporation and the board.

The price of the board's other supplies of heavy fuel oil in the year averaged $169 per tonne. The extra cost to the board of the purchases from the corporation amounted to about £4.8 million. It must be stated that in 1982 the corporation's contracted crude oil supplies were uncompetitive when compared to other crude oil prices. As a result of major changes in the INPC's procurement arrangements made earlier this year, the corresponding figure in 1983 is expected to show a significant improvement.
The extra cost of the price of electricity as a result of the board's purchases from the corporation in 1982 would be equivalent to just under one per cent of the price of electricity.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Energy (Mr. J. Bruton)
Speaker.P: The Industrial Development Authority are committed to the development of industry in Ireland as a whole and resources are allocated to them on this basis and not on a county by county basis.

The distribution of IDA resources is largely related to the number of projects locating in each area and it is not realistic to draw comparisons between any two areas as conditions vary widely from one area to another.
While the IDA encourage industrialists, as far as possible, to locate in less advantaged areas, the final decision is, of course, a matter for each individual company.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Radioactive Fall-out.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if he will outline this nation's preparedness in the event of radioactive fallout by accident or war; the number of persons who are employed in the Civil Defence Force; and if he is satisfied that the force are adequately equipped to deal with such an emergency.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.P: My Department's policy for the protection of the population from the effects of radioactive fallout is based on the idea of domestic refuge rooms prepared by householders themselves and on the ability of the Civil Defence Organisation to predict and monitor radioactivity and to warn and advise the public in relation to it.

From the levels of radiation which might reasonably be expected in this country, the mere fact of staying indoors, in itself, provides a significant protection and this protection factor can be very substantially increased by carrying out simple protective measures. Advice to the public in this regard is contained in my Department's booklet Bás-Beatha which is available free of charge.

The arrangements for detecting, measuring and predicting radioactivity and for warning and advising the public in relation to it have been set up by my Department and these arrangements are tested periodically by means of the Civil Defence National Fallout Exercises.

The Civil Defence Organisation, in which the vast majority of personnel are volunteers, has an aggregate strength in the region of 40,000 but the active strength is probably about half that number. For a fallout situation the required national strength is 4,000 approximately and I am satisfied that that requirement is met and that such personnel are adequately equipped. As their instruments (radiation dose rate survey meters) are becoming obsolete, the Department have placed a contract — with an Irish manufacturer — for a new generation of the entire requirement of these instruments.

MainHeading.P: In relation to any radioactivity-linked peacetime incident, my Department maintain liaison with the Nuclear Energy Board who have responsibilities in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: Over the past ten years approximately 4 per cent of plantings in State forests consisted of broadleaves (hardwoods). Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he is satisfied with the land acquisition policy of his Department and in particular with the operation of the ceiling price per acre policy.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: I am satisfied regarding the arrangements in force in relation to the two aspects mentioned by the Deputy.

The land acquisition policy of my Department is related to the ultimate objective of planting 10,000 hectares per annum. It is recognised, however, that this objective cannot be attained until the reserve of plantable land has been built up to support an annual planting programme of that level. In the short-term a lower target of 7,500 hectares has been adopted as the most practical policy subject to the availability of funds. Therefore, my Department are endeavouring to acquire each year an area of land suitable for afforestation to support the latter programme, any short-fall being met as far as possible by reafforestation of clear-felled land.

As regards the prices paid for land purchased for forestry, these are calculated on a cost-revenue basis in which the timber-bearing potential of the land is the primary factor. Accordingly, lands of higher yield potential will command a higher price. Secondary factors such as likely development costs, including roading, drainage and fencing, are also taken into account in determining land-values.

As a general principle, my Department do not purchase land suitable for agricultural purposes, and to this end it obtains arability reports in all marginal cases. The exclusion of arable land is a further factor in controlling the maximum price which may be paid for forestry land.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell)
Speaker.P: The records of the Department are kept for the Dublin engineering district and not for Dublin City alone.
The Dublin engineering district includes parts of Counties Meath, Kildare and North Wicklow.
The costs of maintenance including all repairs and renewals to telephone kiosks in the Dublin engineering district in 1982 was £261,694. This figure includes £149,878 for malicious damage costs.

There are approximately 930 public telephones in the Dublin engineering district. Eighty-five per cent of these have been converted to payphones and it is expected that the balance will be converted by the end of 1983.

The aluminium type kiosk have been erected in large numbers only since 1982. A number of teething problems experienced with these kiosks have been resolved. Because of the high level of vandalism it is not possible to say at this stage whether this type of kiosk is subject to a lesser degree of vandalism. However, this question is being kept under review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Printing Firms Postal Rates.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if he is aware of the serious loss of business to printing firms in Ireland with a consequent loss of jobs as a result of the absence of any provisions for reduced postal rates for printing firms who post magazines and periodicals which they print; if he will consider introducing a special scheme of reduced postal rates for printers, similar to those operating in many other countries; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell)
Speaker.P: My Department already grant specially reduced rates of postage which printers can avail of for sending magazines and periodicals through the post in the inland and foreign services. Apart from this, the Department have for many years been operating a foreign surface bulk post service, which offers even more substantial reductions to printers. However, as this service is not allowed under the Universal Postal Union Convention to which Ireland is a signatory, and has been operated at a substantial loss, its replacement by a foreign bulk post service arranged bi-laterally with the countries concerned and on an economic basis but still offering significant discounts is now at an advanced planning stage.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rebroadcasting of British TV.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Posts and Telegraphs if he will give details of areas in the country in which British television signals are being rebroadcasted by the illegal deflector system; and further if he will give details of the report he has commissioned in his Department on progress being made with regard to negotiations on copyright with the British broadcasting authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell) Jim Mitchell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Posts and Telegraphs (Mr. J. Mitchell)
Speaker.P: So far as my Department are aware, a number of unlicensed rebroadcasting systems operate in Counties Donegal, Galway, Mayo, Roscommon, Sligo, Tipperary and Waterford. Such systems are liable to seizure and the operators are liable to prosecution.

The negotiations of copyright agreements with broadcasting authorities is a matter for those who wish to use the broadcast signals. My Department's examination of the matter indicates that any such negotiations would be complex and time consuming.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Drugs Smuggling.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the measures he proposes to introduce to reduce the smuggling of drugs through our ports; and if he is prepared to grant full powers of arrest to the customers officers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The Revenue Commissioners state that the most up-to-date drug identification equipment available has been issued to customs staff at ports, airports and at land frontier crossings. Increasing numbers of customs officers have been receiving specialised drug training at the Customs and Excise Training Centre and training officers have visited various stations on an on-going basis to instruct local staff. Two specialist officers have recently been assigned to liaison duties with Garda Authorities and for the development of information and intelligence and to co-ordinate joint actions on both a national and international basis. The effectiveness of these measures will be kept under constant review.

Customs officers have powers of arrest for drug smuggling under the Customs Consolidation Act, 1876. However, in practice persons detected by customs are normally handed over to the Garda who institute proceedings under the Misuse of Drugs Act, 1977.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The Revenue Commissioners are examining the question of providing drug detector dogs for customs purposes. This involves inquiries about the availability of dogs and training of dogs and handlers. Training facilities are not available in this country.

MainHeading.P: In the past customs have availed of the services of a Garda drug detector dog when necessary.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cleaning of Leinster House Complex Exterior.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the ages of the building complex that comprises Leinster House, The National Museum, The National Library, The National Gallery and The Natural History Museum; when the outer stonework of these buildings was last cleaned and restored; if he will outline the approximate cost of cleaning and restoring these buildings; and if it is his intention to carry out such necessary work in the near future given the deplorable condition of some of the frontage.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The approximate ages of Leinster House, the National Museum, the National Library, the National Gallery, and Natural History Museum are 230, 100, 100, 120 and 120 years respectively.
The facade of the original Leinster House was last cleaned during the years 1962 and 1963 and some stone restoration work was carried out in 1965 and 1981.

A major stonework repair programme is proposed for the National Museum. A survey has been carried out and some tests and trial repairs done but further tests are required. It is not possible at this stage to estimate the cost of the work involved or to say when the works can commence.
Renewal of some of the stonework of the National Library was carried out at different periods between 1954 and 1971.
Cleaning of the stonework of the National Gallery was carried out as part of a contract placed in 1964 for the erection of an extension to the building.
The Commissioners of Public Works have no record that any cleaning or restoration of the stonework of the Natural History Museum was carried out.

MainHeading.P: Apart from stonework repairs proposed for the National Museum there are no proposals at present for carrying out cleaning or stone restoration works to the other buildings mentioned in the question.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Trade, Commerce and Tourism (Mr. Cluskey)

This treatment is carried out by orthodontists in private practice on behalf of the health boards and in normal circumstances treatment of the case in question would now be in progress. However, the Department of Health have been endeavouring for the past two years to get agreement with the private orthodontists on a scale of charges for the treatment and in the absence of agreement the issue of authorisations to proceed with treatments was suspended. The Department have recently put proposals for a fee scale to the orthodontists. If the orthodontists agree to these proposals then the Department will be in a position to recommence the issue of authorisations to health boards to proceed with fixed appliance cases.

Applications will be invited soon for a new full-time post of consultant orthodontist for the Western Health Board. The filling of this post should greatly reduce the waiting period for orthodontic treatment in the area.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

She is aware of her possible entitlement to an increase in respect of the child and a form on which to claim the increase has been sent to her. She has been advised that this form should be completed and returned when the child resumes full-time education after the holiday period. Her entitlement to an increase in respect of the child will then be considered and if in order will be back-dated to 10 June 1983.

Speaker.P: Limerick East): I propose to take Questions Nos. 995 and 996 together.

Under the provisions of section 9.2.1 of the scheme of Civil Legal Aid and Advice, the Legal Aid Board is obliged to make an annual report to the Minister for Justice on the operation of the Scheme and copies of these are required to be laid before each House of the Oireachtas by the Minister for Justice. The board's published reports for the years 1980 and 1981 contain the information requested by the Deputy in regard to applications for and refusals of legal aid and I expect that similar information in respect of the board's operations in 1982 will be contained in the board's report for that year when it is published.
In addition the board have provided the following information in relation to appeals against refusals to grant legal aid.

MainHeading.P: The board have informed me that the appeal committee normally meet once every month. It consists of the chairman of the board who is a senior counsel and four ordinary members of the board, of whom two are practising barristers or solicitors.
I am informed that none of the remaining statistics requested by the Deputy is available and they could not be compiled without serious disruption of the board's work.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will allow a prisoner (details supplied) in County Laois to visit his mother who is in Musgrave Park Hospital suffering from two strokes and who according to doctors is deteriorating rapidly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): As has been explained on other cases, it is not the practice for Ministers for Justice to say publicly, either in response to parliamentary questions or otherwise, whether or when a prisoner may be released on compassionate grounds or for other reasons. In the particular case referred to in the question it is public knowledge that there are very exceptional considerations which create difficulties beyond the normal.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Land Deal.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when a decision will be made by the Land Registry on a dealing (details supplied) in County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that this is an application for first registration which was lodged in the Land Registry on 24 May 1983. It is being processed at present.

Applications such as this involve detailed and complex examination of title and often protracted correspondence with solicitors as well as the issue of statutory notices to interested parties which usually gives rise to further correspondence. Average delays at present in completing such cases are unlikely to be less than 12 months.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Limerick Garda Cars.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will make a statement on the reasons a Garda car is not being provided for Kilmallock Garda district, County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): I am informed by the Garda authorities that they consider that the existing arrangements whereby the Kilmallock area is covered by mobile patrols operated from the district headquarters at Bruff and by the Divisional Task Force and the Traffic Corps based at Henry Street, Limerick, are adequate and make the best use of manpower and transport resources. Accordingly, they do not propose to allocate a patrol car to Kilmallock station at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will make a statement on the reason a Garda car is not being provided for Patrickswell Garda district, County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The allocation of official transport to individual stations is a matter for the Garda authorities. They report that there are no proposals to assign a patrol car to Patrickswell station as they consider that the present arrangements make the best use of manpower resources at present available.
I am informed, however, that a motor cycle may be allocated to Patrickswell station at a later stage.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rosslare Strand (Wexford) Garda Strength.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the concern among the people of Rosslare Strand, County Wexford, that sufficient gardaí are not available in the area; and if he will ensure the presence of at least one garda at all times.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The detailed deployment of Garda manpower is a matter for the Garda authorities who report that an additional garda will shortly be assigned to Rosslare Strand station to meet any increased demands on Garda services during the summer season. Apart from the service provided from the local station, the Rosslare Strand area also receives attention from mobile patrols operated by uniform and plainclothes units based at the divisional headquarters at Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when a letter of sanction will be issued to the board of management of St. Joseph's primary school, Oliver Plunkett Hill, Fermoy, County Cork, for the erection of an extension of two classrooms and toilet facilities to solve the very serious existing overcrowding problem there.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when a letter of sanction will be issued to the board of management of St. Joseph's primary school, Oliver Plunkett Hill, Fermoy, County Cork, for the erection of the necessary extension to the school; and the reason for the delay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 1002 and 1007 together. The need for additional accommodation at St. Joseph's National School, Oliver Plunkett Hill, Fermoy, County Cork, is being considered in the context of the accommodation requirements of the area in general. My Department's examination of the case will be completed as soon as possible and a decision will then be conveyed to the chairman.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position regarding Brooklodge second level school, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: County Cork Vocational Education Committee have bought a site for a new second-level school to serve the Glanmire and Riverstown area. The timing and pupil capacity of the proposed new school have not yet been decided. The situation will be reviewed when enrolments in primary and post-primary schools in the general area for 1983-84 are available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the teaching of religious education has been affected by the recent staffing cutbacks, particularly in the smaller post-primary schools; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if the cutback in staffing for post primary schools had any effect on the curriculum being offered by the schools concerned; and, if so, the provisions being made for students in the senior cycle in these schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 1004 and 1005 together. The revised staffing arrangements for post primary schools will not take effect until the commencement of the next school year. I do not accept the implications in the questions that the implementation of the new regulations will result in undue difficulty in the formulation of school time-tables for the purpose of including suitable provision for the subjects on the curriculum of the schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if an extra allocation of approximately four hours in schools with under 250 pupils has been granted to compensate for the difference between the 18 hours vice-principals need to teach and the 22 hours which all in-service teachers who are in quota are bound to teach.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The matter of the number of teaching hours required for eligibility for the purpose of the rules for payment of incremental salary is not affected by whether or not such salary is being paid to a vice-principal as a teacher inside or outside the quota of teachers specified in the case of the school concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the stage at which the plans are for the proposed extension to Fr. Griffin Road vocational school, Galway; the factors causing the delay; if the land needed for the extension has yet been acquired; and when it is expected that work on the extension will be started.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: There has been no undue delay in the processing of proposals from Galway Vocational Education Committee for the extension of the vocational school at Fr. Griffin Road. Negotiations are proceeding for the purchase of additional land in order to enable the extension to be undertaken. Discussions are also under way with the vocational committee in relation to the accommodation to be provided. As the planning of the extension is at an early stage, it is not possible to say now when work on the extension will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the progress, if any, made on the extension of Magheraroarty national school, Gortahork, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department await the submission of sketch-plans for the proposed extension to Magheraroarty national school, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the position in relation to the request to reopen the national school at Bunaninver, Derrybeg, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Bun an Inbhir national school was amalgamated with Scoil Adhamhnain, Luinniagh in January 1969. The then Minister subsequently released his interest in the school building. Without prejudice to the existing educational arrangements in the area I am having the matter examined in the light of indications I have received of a demand for the reopening of the school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Foley Mr. Foley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will arrange for transport for persons (details supplied) in County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The children in question, who have always attended Kilflynn national school, are not eligible for free transport to that school on age/distance grounds, since reaching the age of ten years.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Teacher Appointment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason she has not sanctioned the appointment of a teacher of French at St. Raphael's College, Loughrea, County Galway, to replace a former teacher, now deceased; and when this appointment will be made.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department determine in accordance with the rules for the payment of incremental salary to secondary teachers the number of teachers to whom incremental salary may be paid. Within this number it is a matter for school management to decide how best it will cater for the needs and aptitudes of its pupils.
The school authorities have been informed as to the number of teachers to whom incremental salary may be paid in 1983-84.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason she has not sanctioned a computer grant for St. Raphael's College, Loughrea, County Galway; and when she will do so.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: A grant was sanctioned for the purpose of computer equipment in the case of the school in question in 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if allowances are being made to parents who paid for school bus tickets between January and May 1983; if she will make the necessary adjustments in calculating charges for the next school term; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to a reply to Questions Nos. 925 and 926 on Tuesday, 26 April 1983, in which it was stated that parents who had paid school transport charges in respect of pupils who qualified for exemption because their parents/legal guardians were holders of a medical card should apply directly to the local CIE office for a refund.
The charges payable in the school year 1983-84 will be those specified in the relevant school transport circulars.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the position concerning the proposed primary school for Brookfield, Tallaght, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The chairman of the board of management of Brookfield national school, Tallaght, County Dublin, was authorised on 13 May last to arrange for the planning of a second school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will provide an extra teacher for St. Paul's secondary school, Greenhills, Dublin 12.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will sanction an additional teacher for St. Paul's secondary school, Greenhills, Dublin 12, which is urgently required due to the rise in the number of pupils.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 1016 and 1017 together.

The appointment of teachers in secondary schools under the prescribed regulations and within the authorised quotas of staff is a matter for the managerial authorities of the schools. An appeal was received by the Department from the authorities of the school in question in relation to the quota of teachers to whom incremental salary would be paid in the 1983-84 school year. Having considered the views of the Quota Advisory Review Committee, the Department have conveyed its decision in the matter to the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Allen Mr. Allen
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason there are so few A and B grades awarded in the leaving certificate examination for modern languages.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I am not aware of the basis of the question from the Deputy and, accordingly, I am not in a position to offer observations on it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Ahern Mr. M. Ahern
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education (a) the reason students from Killeagh, County Cork who attend secondary schools in Midleton, County Cork, were not allowed to board the school bus at the boundary of the catchment area, which would have meant a saving of 30p per day per student; (b) if it is intended to operate the same school transport system from Killeagh to Midleton in the coming term; and (c) the reason the school bus did not operate from Killeagh to Midleton during the examination period.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Post-Primary pupils from Killeagh who avail of transport on the scheduled service to Midleton centre may board the bus at any point along the route and my information is that they have not been prevented from doing so.

The scheduled service from Killeagh to Midleton operated during the examination period and the vehicles in question had sufficient accommodation for all children who were sitting for the examinations.
The scheduled services from Youghal via Killeagh to Midleton may continue to be used to facilitate eligible pupils who apply for transport to Midleton centre.
Scheduled services as distinct from special school services, are operated by CIE and are the responsibility of the company and my Department have no function in their operation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Brennan Mr. M. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when the proposed new school for Moylough, Tubbercurry, County Sligo, will be sanctioned by her Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: My Department await a report from the Commissioners of Public Works concerning the suitability of the site offered by the chairman for the proposed new national school at Moylough, Tubbercurry, County Sligo.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she will agree to provide a grant of £25,000 to enable the National Association of Adult Education (Aontas) to survive to the end of the current financial year; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 1021, 1022 and 1023 together.
The grant-in-aid for Aontas in Vote 28 subhead G.1. for 1983 is £52,000.
I would like to point out to the Deputies that the grant-in-aid for this association has been increased over the last few years as follows:

MainHeading.P: It is considered that the increases made in the grant-in-aid for this association have been generous in the context of the present financial difficulties. In this regard it will be noted that in 1982 the grant-in-aid was increased to more than three times the 1981 grant.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Youghal (Cork) School.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Ahern Mr. M. Ahern
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if she intends to maintain two teachers at the South Abbey national school, Youghal, County Cork; and, if not, the reason.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: A temporary assistant teacher for South Abbey national school was approved as an exceptional matter for the school year 1982-83 on the understanding that pupil numbers would increase to justify the appointment under the rules.

MainHeading.P: The case is at present being re-examined in the light of present and future enrolment trends and a decision will be conveyed to the chairman of the board of management as soon as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons

Arrangements have been made for accommodating extra pupils in temporary premises in the school-year 1983-84.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gene Fitzgerald Mr. Gene Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when work on the second level school in Passage West, County Cork, will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Brennan Mr. M. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the position regarding finance being made available for extra classrooms, extensions, etc., for Mullaghroe national school, via Boyle, County Sligo.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The long-term accommodation requirements of Mullaghroe national school, County Sligo, are being considered at present. When a decision has been taken, the chairman will be notified without delay. The question of sanctioning a grant does not arise at this stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Staffing arrangements in St. Mary's Place national school for the 1983-84 school year are being considered at present in the context of a review of the staffing levels generally in inner city schools.
Question No. 1029 withdrawn.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Coláiste Gaeilge i gContae na Gallimhe.
MainHeading.P: 1030. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: den Aire Oideachais-cén t-údar gur diúltaíodh cead d'Udarás Choláiste Gaeilge i gContae na Gaillimhe (sonraí tugtha) ranganna a thionól i bhfoirgneamh áirithe agus céard iad na feabhsúcháin a bheadh riachtanach lena chur in ord.

Speaker.hpid: Aire Oideachais (Mrs. Hussey) Aire Oideachais (Mrs. Hussey)
Speaker.P: Níl aon Roinn sásta aitheantas a thabhairt do choláiste ar bith a chuireann ranganna agus imeachtaí eile ar súil sa halla atá i gceist anseo.

Caithfear oibreacha áirithe a dhéanamh ar an gcóras uisce, ar an urlár agus ar an díon agus teastaisí a sholáthar óailtire, ón oifigeach sláintíochta agus ón oifigeach dóiteáin ag deimhniú go bhfuil an halla curtha in oiriúnt agus sabháilte do dhaltaí mar atá leagtha síos in alt a cúig dena coinníollacha a mbaineann le scéim deontais na gcoláistí samhraidh.
